doc.title: EVERCORE ISI
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Best Buy Co. Inc.Best Buy Co. Inc._2025-08-29

passages.text: Consumer | Retail Broadlines & Hardline
BBY| \(\) 72.53\$ In Line | Target Price/Base Case: \(\) 72.00\(\) \ \(75.00)\) Earnings Report
1 Year Price History

Best Buy's +1.6% 2Q comp, the best result since 3Q21, provides hope for a return to EPS growth into 2026. Sales momentum in June/July continued into August, and mgmt. guided 3Q sales 150bp above consensus. The catch is the full- year EPS guide (Comps \((- / + 1\%)\) and EPS of \(\) 6.15\(to\) \ \(6.30\) was maintained despite the top line strength, signaling a lack of flow through. Our RSLI suggests a modest 2H decel as tariff driven pricing flows in before Trump 2.0 stimulus helps in '26. For BBY, innovation remains critical to driving consumer engagement, with Switch 2, Windows 10 phase out, and mobile phone initiatives driving hopes. Increased breadth & depth of promotion is expected into holiday, weighing on gross margins with partial offset coming from marketplace, services, and ads. Bulls emphasize sales pickup, traffic stabilizing (fig 5), new businesses in ads/marketplace, rate cuts on tap and \(\) 7\(EPS potential to push the stock price to\) \ \(100\) (14x). Bears obsess about longer term share, traffic and margin declines which will cap the multiple regardless of periodic pops. A 10x multiple on down EPS could take the stock back to \(\) 60\(. We land in the middle. Mgmt's history of controlling costs, plus initiatives in new profit streams while focusing on long term relevancy are sound. We see catalysts for C25 EPS to bottom\) >\$6, with growth again in C26 to \(\) 6.40\$ Competition won't get easier & growing sub- GDP suggests a muted multiple. Our Base Case of \(\) 77\(reflecting \~12x our C26e EPS.

What we liked: Comps. Vendor Relationships. Digital. Alternative Revenue Streams. Cost Mgmt. \(+1.6\%\) comp is the best since 3Q21 and Switch wasn't the only driver. Computing posted its \(6^{\text{th}}\) consecutive positive quarter, with 2Q marking the highest number of laptop unit sales in 15 years. BBY's strong vendor relationships remain supportive with innovation, tariff mitigation, and even in labor (expecting \(20\%\) more investment y/y in 2H) to help sales flow. Digital grew to \(33\%\) of domestic sales, aiding BBY Ads and marketplace rollout; both support margins while underpinning BBY's CE relevancy. BBY remains on top of restructuring, with a \(\) 114\(mn charge (\) \ \(40m non - cash)\) to remain lean. SG&A leverage likely for the full year, helping hold EBIT margins \(>4\%\)

What to watch: Tariff impacts. Share Pressure. Appliances. '26 Catalysts. Tariffs remain a wildcard throughout retail, with price elasticity in CE and U.S. consumption still to be seen. Increased ASPs could tire out an already value- focused consumer. BBY believes they at least held share during 2Q, yet remains an overhang given the comp performance since 2019. Appliances remain soft (- 8%), vs HD, LOW & COST gains. The IKEA partnership, lower I- rates, and stimulus could aid 2026, yet remain on the come.

Bottom Line: BBY is managing secular & cyclical pressures; recent sales gains are a good thing. The \(5\%\) dividend & low valuation provide support until new revenue streams mature. That said, sales are \(\sim\) \(\) 2bn\((- 5\%)\) lower than 2019, EBIT margins are down 70bps (to \(4.2\%\) ), and EPS are flat with on a \(\sim 20\%\) lower share base; one year of LSD comps are unlikely to turn the multiple. BBY competes against WMT, AMZN, COST & HD. Share & returns will be hard to turn, with the optionality of growing omni and new businesses the key upside hopes.

Best Buy's \(+1.6\%\) 2Q comp, the best result since 3Q21, provides hope for a return to EPS growth into 2026. Sales momentum in June/July continued into August, and mgmt. guided 3Q sales 150bp above consensus. The catch is the full- year EPS guide (Comps \((- / + 1\%)\) and EPS of \(\) 6.15\(to\) \ \(6.30\) ) was maintained despite the top line strength, signaling a lack of flow through. Our RSLI is suggests modest 2H decel as tariff driven pricing flows in before Trump 2.0 stimulus helps in '26. For BBY, innovation remains critical to driving consumer engagement, with Switch 2, Windows 10 phase out, and mobile phone initiatives driving hopes. Increased breadth & depth of promotion is expected into holiday, weighing on gross margins with partial offset coming from marketplace, services, and ads. Bulls emphasize sales pickup, traffic stabilizing (fig 5), new businesses in ads/marketplace, rate cuts on tap and \(\) 7\$ EPS potential to push the stock price to \(\) 100\(14x). Bears obsess about longer term share, traffic and margin declines which will cap the multiple regardless of periodic pops. A 10x multiple on down EPS could take the stock back to \(\) 60\(. We land in the middle. Mgmt. history of controlling costs, plus initiatives in new profit streams while focusing on long term relevancy are sound. We see catalysts for C25 EPS to bottom\) \geq \\(6, with growth again in C26 to\) \ \(6.40\) . Competition won't get easier & growing sub- GDP suggests a muted multiple. Our Base Case of \(\) 77\(reflecting \~12x our C26e EPS.\)

What we liked: Comps. Vendor Relationships. Alternative Revenue Streams. Cost Mgmt. 2Q's \(+1.6\%\) comp is the best since 3Q21 and while the Switch certainly boosted the result, gaming saw additional growth outside of the Nintendo hit. Computing remains strong with the \(6^{\text{th}}\) consecutive quarter of positive growth and 2Q marking the highest number of 2Q laptop unit sales in 15 years. Best Buy's strong vendor relationships remain supportive also with top vendors investing in labor (expecting \(20\%\) more labor investment y/y in 2H) to help sales flow. Vendors rightfully view BBY's real estate as an asset with the recent IKEA partnership an example of that. The implementation & rollout of Best Buy Ads and the U.S. marketplace is expected to serve as a tailwind to gross margin rate. The growth in these two areas is key as adding incremental rev/profit streams is key to keeping Best Buy relevant in the broader consumer electronics space. While comps did improve in 2Q/August, BBY is still managing expenses thoroughly with SG&A leverage likely for the full year and helping in keeping margins from falling further.

What to watch: Tariff Implications. Share Pressure. Appliances. '26 Catalysts. Tariffs remain a wildcard throughout retail and not only do vendor/BBY discussions around price points cause concern, but the greater impact on the U.S. consumer as increased ASPs likely tire out an already value- conscious consumer. Reminder, our RSLI is signaling a modest slowdown in spend across retail. BBY believes they at least held share during 2Q but remains an overhang given the cumulative comp performance since 2019. Appliances in particular remain soft (- 8%), while HD and LOW recently called out majors as an area of strength. The IKEA partnership + potential interest rate ease could offer support, but that is to be seen still. With the Switch launch and Windows 10 expiration providing support from 2Q, the question will turn to any catalysts to help comps through '26. Continued innovation within computing & tablets in regard to AI provide some hope here.

Category Highlights: Appliances remained weak, down HSD once again. The appliances market, which is currently mostly driven by breakage in a weak housing market is putting pressure on BBY's market share. Computing & mobile (45% of sales) comped \(+3.8\%\) in 2Q, decelerating from 1Q but strong, nonetheless. Electronics (hello Switch) comped up \(38\%\) , the best of the bunch and continued growth (more modest) is expected into 2H. Consumer electronics, the \(2^{\text{nd}}\) biggest category, came in weak, down \(4.9\%\) (on top of - \(6.2\%\) in 2Q24) Services (7% of sales) comped down \(1\%\) .

Bottom Line: Best Buy has made a great effort managing though the secular and cyclical pressures at play. The 2Q top line strength helps and momentum has continued into August. The reality remains BBY has lost share for some time now but the healthy dividend, low valuation, and proven mgmt. can help provide support while new revenue streams mature. That said, sales are nominally \(- \Phi 2bn\) ( \(- 5\%\) ) lower than 2019, EBIT margins are down 70bps (to \(4.2\%\) ), and EPS have remained effectively flat on a share count \(- 20\%\) lower. Hard to see the multiple sustaining a meaningful turn in that backdrop. 2Q was a nice reminder that BBY can still win when the environment is T'd up with the strong performance through a key product launch. But whereas Best Buy was able to gain share from Sears, Circuit City, HH Gregg, and RadioShack in the past, they are now competing against Walmart, Amazon, Costco and Home Depot. That will likely keep hope of a share and/or margin turn in check, with the optionality of a growing omnichannel and new business presence the longer- term hope for upside.

Bull Case - $94Base Case - $77Bear Case - $5514x Bull Case 2026e EPS of $6.7012x Base Case 2026e EPS of $6.4010x Bear Case 2026e EPS of $5.50What tariffs? What competition? BBY successfully turns comps around and takes share while doing it: +MSD into 2026. Topline growth, alternative profit streams, and adj. labor spend can push margins to pre-pandemic 5% levels. The membership model is a long-term boon to profits, particularly as big-ticket units return. Services drive sticky traffic and ticket. Share repurchases ramp and dividend growth remain. The market is willing to give a 14x multiple to BBY given dividend and perceived recovery in demand and margins.Turning EPS positive again. 2025 and 2026 see some than 22 and 23. Slightly pos comps by the end of '25 show momentum into stimulus in 2026 – but this sub-sector is far from healthy. Margins are likely stuck at ~4% until comp growth can consistently exceed 2%. This is effectively the decade's troubling point. Longer term, recovery is likely dependent on alternative segment profitability and a meaningful innovation/ replacement cycle or at least market share stability. Continued dividends provide support to BBY at a market discount.The cycle proves long and deep. Efforts today prove fleeting through 2025. Share slippage is real, as the industry sees a positive inflection while BBY comps remains down in 2025. Margin headwinds from promotional activity, normalized compensation, and improved digital capabilities remain – while tailwinds from operational changes are realized as anticipated but lack continued yearly lift. The dividend provides support, but is called into question as the payout ration approaches 100%. Margins sub 4% and structurally compressed long-term.
Source:Company Data,FactSet,Evercore ISI Research

The competitive landscape is getting tougher. With Circuit City, Radioshack, and hhgregg as competitors long gone, Best Buy is the last major national CE specialist that now competes as much with Walmart and Costco as with Amazon. Each operates at a lower gross margin rate and have other businesses to offset potential category headwinds.

Operating margins for BBY are similar offline and online. BBY has stated that on an annual basis, their online operating margin is equal to its in- store margin. Several years of investing in multichannel has paid off. That might translate into more store closings over time.

Where do comps go from here? Comps will likely be down for CY25 with the hope that 2H momentum can develop and be sustained into CY26. There is hope for an eventual replacement to catch on that would likely help BBY sustain multiple quarters of positive comps, but hard to underwrite in the current environment. Promotional activity will be next to come into question as retailers willing to slash prices to spur discretionary sales will likely see unit growth above the industry. BBY hasn't given indications that they are promoting significantly beyond what their vendors support but could start to do so if they see sales compression, further delays to the replacement cycle and muted consumer reaction to innovation. If all goes well, comps are hopefully positive by year end.

1. The replacement cycle takes hold and consumers look to re-purchase pandemic-stimulus purchases  
2. Innovation & new product launches drive both high and low end spend (on discounted legacy products), providing support to comp traffic  
3. Alternative profit streams enable BBY to recover margins above 4%

1. Macro and consumer constraints extend ... hitting BBY's topline and delinquencies.  
2. Tariffs hit consumer unit demand, pressuring comps and margins in big ticket categories  
3. 2/3 of phone activations happen at carrier stores, or Apple stores  
4. LOW & HD make push to win the appliance category - and easy share gains from Sears are behind them  
5. Innovation cycle proves wanting and marketing spend to highlight new launches wastes needed capital

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:

Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector. Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances. Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
